head.title: Restaurants in The Netherlands - Lonely Planet

meta.content: Lonely Planet travellers are voting for the best restaurant in The Netherlands. #1 Bagels & Beans, #2 Van Dobben, #3 Thais Snackbar Bird, #4 Pancake Bakery, #5 Japanese Pancake World.
meta.name: description

a.class: nav__item nav__item--primary nav__item--user user-basket js-user-basket js-nav-cart

div.p: Join the crowds for bagels with all the usual toppings, plus some new-fangled ones (smoked chicken with avocado and pesto). Top it all off with a slice of dense fig cake; it goes exceedingly well with coffee. It has another branch in De Pijp (Ferdinand Bolstraat 70).

It has been open since the 1940s, the venerable Van Dobben has white tiled walls and white-coated counter men who specialise in snappy banter. Traditional meaty Dutch fare is the forte: try the pekelvlees (something close to corned beef), or make it a halfom, if youâ€™re keen on that being mixed with liver. The kroketten (croquettes) are the best in town and compulsory after a late-night Rembrandtplein booze-up.

Donâ€™t tell the Chinese neighbours, but this is some of the best Asian food on the Zeedijk â€“ the cooks, wedged in a tiny kitchen, donâ€™t skimp on lemongrass, fish sauce or chilli. The resulting curries and basil-laden meat and seafood dishes will knock your socks off. Thereâ€™s a bit more room to spread out in the (slightly pricier) restaurant across the street (No 72).

This basement restaurant in a restored warehouse features a dizzying 79 varieties of pancakes, from sweet (chocolate) to savoury (the â€˜Egyptianâ€™, topped with lamb, sweet peppers and garlic sauce). There are also omelettes, soups, desserts and lots of tourists given its proximity to the Anne Frank Huis.

If the Dutch are famous for pancakes of meat, seafood and vegies, so are the Japanese. At the continentâ€™s only shop specialising in okonomiyaki (literally â€˜cook as you likeâ€™), youâ€™ll get yours in a hot iron dish with your choice of fillings, topped with flakes of dried fish. Thereâ€™s a J-pop backdrop and barely two dozen seats.

Owners Hector and Pedro consistently set the standard among Amsterdamâ€™s handful of Mexican restaurants. If youâ€™re looking for wonderfully grilled bistek (beefsteak), crispy chicken rolls and fruity margaritas, youâ€™re definitely in the right place. A few shots from the 60-plus tequila list, and youâ€™ll be ready for a hat dance.

Tapas and only tapas. The alluringly tiled exterior is matched by a vibrant crowd inside, especially on weekends, downing sangria by the jug and all those small plates (the garlic-fried shrimps and grilled sardines are standouts). Margaritas are made with freshly squeezed lime juice, as they should be. Arrive before 6.30pm or reserve.

In a glorious former Dutch Reformed Church, the light-filled, Middle Eastern-style decor matches the Middle Eastern-style food. Fish and chicken dishes please meat eaters; aubergine and portobello mushroom dishes gratify vegetarians. Breakfast and lunch are served all day.

This huge Hong Kong-style restaurant with the requisite red lanterns is always lively. Join gaggles of local Chinese for daily dim sum (11:30 to 16:30; we like the meaty, flavoursome cha sieuw bao pork buns) and a 24-page menu (!) of classic Canto cuisine.

Puur! is health-food heaven; its bagels, sandwiches, salads and sweets are not only made from organic ingredients, they also taste divine. It's hard to pass over the coffee, tea and freshly squeezed juices on offer too, and everything is either eat-in or takeaway.

Blauw is the place for stylish Indonesian food in Utrecht. Young and old alike enjoy superb rijsttafels (array of spicy dishes served with rice) amid the red decor that mixes vintage art with hip minimalism.

This casual, elegant, wood-panelled restaurant doesn't take itself too seriously (the name means 'access forbidden'). The grub's top-notch, with an emphasis on seafood - try the butterfish in white wine.
As carefully arranged as a bento box, Ginger takes inspiration from Thailand to Japan, China to Bali. The menu bursts with goodness and authentic Asian flavours â€“ hence the name.
It wonâ€™t win any design awards, but Nam Kee is the most popular Chinese spot in town. Thereâ€™s a new, fancier location at Geldersekade 117.
Unique, offbeat and cosy - try the kangaroo dish cooked French-provincial style.

This family-friendly cafe sits right on the hot-and-heavy Warmoesstraat and offers excellent baked goods (especially scones), sandwiches, soups, and breakfast fare like quiche, French toast and omelettes. A smaller outlet pops up down the block at Warmoesstraat 133 , serving sandwiches on wonderfully crusty bread and fresh-squeezed juices for takeaway.

Admired by gourmets city-wide, De Kas has an organic attitude to match its chic glass greenhouse setting. It grows most of its own herbs and produce right there, and the result is incredibly pure flavours with innovative combinations. Thereâ€™s one set menu each day, based on whatever has been freshly harvested.

One of the city's hippest eateries is housed in a former water-processing plant. Expect classic French brasserie cooking (steak bearnaise, mussels, roasted garlic chicken). Note the 30m wooden ceilings (with hanging metal hooks and chains) and the huge floodlights rescued from the former Ajax and Olympic stadiums.

Youâ€™d never guess that this smart-looking place was once a restaurant for the poor. It still keeps up that heritage, though, with decent cooking (think stamppot or couscous) at exceedingly decent prices. The service can be a bit surly â€“ just consider it part of the cultural experience.

When the weatherâ€™s good, thereâ€™s nothing quite like enjoying a crema de ajo (cream of garlic) soup or lomo saltado (beef with onion, tomato and French fries) while looking out over the Leidsegracht and the Prinsengracht. Indoors, itâ€™s busy and homelike.

Tucked away in a long, often graffiti-covered alley in the middle of the Red Light District, this charming 17th-century herb warehouse (complete with exposed brick and steel weights) is the setting for contemporary French- and Italian-inspired cooking. In summer, grab a table in the garden.

One of a gaggle of swank cafes on the vast Plein. Rest your gentrified butt on the comfy wicker chairs and watch the pigeons bedevil the solemn statue of Willem Den Eerste, hero of the Spanish war. No telling what the famous nationalist would have thought about Cloosâ€™ Italian menu.

A lovely place that's more elegant than its moniker might imply. It's won a swag of 'Lekkers' (the Dutch restaurant-awards) and has crisp, white tablecloths, a dainty dining room, and delicious and immaculately prepared meat, poultry and vegetable concoctions with a haute cuisine feel.

Never tried Kurdish food? Neither had we, but weâ€™re glad we did. Just as Kurdistan straddles Turkey and Iran, so does the cuisine, with grills and stews (mostly lamb and chicken), salads of cucumber, tomato or onion, and starters like hummus and dumast (thick, dry yoghurt).

Flamenco music (Saturday night), big shared tables and reasonably priced tapas guarantee Duende's popularity. It's great for a party with a big group of friends - or strangers. The front room is the more lively (and attractive) of the two. Note: order at the bar.
